Also am glad recently Nintendo has FINALLY put their arcade classics for download on the Switches “Arcade Archives” so now I don’t have to play the weak NES ports of Donkey Kong, Popeye, Mario Bros. anymore. A contributing factor this video doesn't mention is retail glut. Retailers were massively overordering games from the manufacturers, who were required at the time to accept unsold returns and eat the loss. The smaller 3rd party companies simply couldn't take the hit, and the dominoes began to fall, beginning with Data Age (who deserved it) and eventually destroying companies like Imagic (who DIDN'T deserve it).

And Atari is still garbage to this day. Now their issue is not rushing products, but strangling people with their patents in a misguided attempt to hold on to their licenses. A lesson they "learned" from their early years with the Atari 2600. It has made them hated by the crowd of the older generation who should be feeling nostalgia, not dejection. This attitude has actually killed their games forever when they shut down sites dedicated to perseving games that they (Atari) can no longer afford to support with their meager budget.

Donkey Kong's name origin is only... partially accurate.  At the time Miyamoto didn't have the firmest grasp on the english language, and he wanted a name that conveyed something stubborn, foolish, stupid, etc.  He wanted something like "Moron Kong" or "Dummy Kong", and thought that donkey meant something along those lines.  The people he pitched the name to laughed and laughed at it, but they ended up loving it and it stuck.

Did you know that the original name for Pac-Man was Puck-Man? You'd think it was because he looks like a hockey puck but it actually comes from the Japanese phrase 'Paku-Paku,' which means to flap one's mouth open and closed. They changed it because they thought Puck-Man would be too easy to vandalize, you know, like people could just scratch off the P and turn it into an F or whatever.

The Commodore 64 was still going gang-busters in Britain/Europe, Japan was still crapping out games and arcades were an institution. .

There is a reason it's called the "Great North American Video Game Crash." It's because the Crash only really affected the USA and Canada. Everywhere else - particularly Europe and Japan - were virtually unaffected. Nintendo was also unaffected by the Crash because it was still in Japan at the time.

Cool trivia: the editors for this episode used a rather curious version of "Pitfall!" for the clip. Anyone notice the "CCE" logo where the "Activision" logo should be? (6:28) Due to government restrictions in Brazil at the time (yes, Brazil), international companies had very little access to the country to enjoy its market potential. So Brazilian companies (like "CCE" and many others) made a huge profit by cloning all kinds of consumer electronics like the Atari console, the Apple II and ZX Spectrum computers. They would also clone the software (Pitfall! in this case) and insert their own logo into it. Because of this commercial blockade, rights holders also could not prosecute these companies. It was only in the early 90's that companies like Nintendo could lawfully enter the market, sell their products and fight piracy, cloning and IP misuse.

I'm very disappointed in Crash Course for repeating bad history. Some key points:

- Atari Pacman was well received and sold well despite being a terrible port. (A prototype in fact.) The problem was that Atari management manufactured more carts than consoles thinking the game would cause a massive surge in console sales!

- ET was not a bad game, despite its rushed development. It was actually an early puzzle adventure game. It was definitely ahead of its time, though, and did not play well to the action-craving children of the time. If you take the time to learn the game (i.e. read the manual) you'll find that most of the complaints vaporize.

- ET did not cause the downfall of the industry, though a similar overproduction problem to Pacman did not help Atari's situation.

- By 1983 the market was oversaturated with product and competitors. This would have caused a normal recession (and subsequent correction) in the market, except for one thing...

- Jack Tramiel had a price war with Texas Instruments at exactly the wrong time. The Commodore 64 with its high-margin software came crashing through the price ceiling that separated computers from game consoles. Retailers flushed their stock of console games at ridiculously low prices and replaced it all with computer systems and software.

- Nintendo did relatively few things to keep quality high. They actually focused on maintaining a limited supply of exclusive product to ensure prices remained high. This also strangled competitors and prevented another industry crash.

- Nintendo's genius was actually marketing the NES as a toy rather than a game console. This put the system on different shelves than the Atari had been and convinced retailers to take on a "video game console". This pretense was dropped once the NES was a runaway success.

That's just a few points. Guys like Marty Goldberg and Curt Vendel can give you a far more detailed scoop. They're well known and respected in the field of video game history and would have been easy to contact.

I'm really disappointed at the quality of journalism on display here. :(

I'm disappointed in this episode, it perpetrates a number of false beliefs:
* The crash was world wide. Yes, you mention 'North America', but briefly, and then continue on to talk about the crash as if it were worldwide. It really only affected North America, countries like Japan, England, Australia and so on were largely unaffected.
* The myth that the rest of the ET cartridges were in that landfill. Yes that landfill had ET cartridges, but it also had a lot of other ones, and not the millions mentioned. It was a dump for a lot of unsold cartridges, but that's about it.
* Not doing much to dispel the myth that it was ET that kind of caused the crash

This was very US centric, and didn't bring good research to the table. Not very happy with it :(
That landfill was a resting place for more than just ET carts- even good 2600 games, such as Defender, were dumped there.

Actually very few cartridges were buried at the famous site, and they wernt all ET games either, there were also games like pacman, which had about 5 million excess copies compared to et's 3.5 million. Most cartridges were held in storage in california, and we're buried in various landfills there.
Also (this is just more stupid and funny than anything) the marketing team for pacman made 12 million copies of the game. Why is that ridiculous? there had only been 10 million Atari 2600s sold and the best selling game at the time had sold about 4 million copies. Pacman was the best selling game for the Atari 2600 but still had 5 million copies left unsold, and only barely scraped a profit. As I said, stupid.

Lore is that Ms. Pac-Man started out as an MIT thesis project but when the student found out that, if presented, MIT would own the code, he instead decided to drop out of college sell the game instead. The proceeds helped fund the founding of General Computer Corporation (GCC). The company went on to create quite a few more video games and then successfully pivoted to becoming a Mac peripheral maker, introducing one of the first non-Apple laser printers on the market.

(A number of my friends worked for GCC in the early 80's)

)

The original Japanese name used the English word "Puck." However the Japanese don't have an "uh" sound, so when rendered into Japanese it becomes パック, Pakku. (With in ah-sound). Also, in Japanese Paku-paku, is an onomatopoeic word for eating (like om-nom-nom).

My brother and I played the heck out of E.T. for the Atari. It wasn't that bad a game. It could be beaten, there was an ending (Spoiler: E.T. went home) it had a consistent world map, and (for Atari 2600) decent graphics. It was no H.E.R.O. or Pitfall II, but it was better than the reputation it got.

Donkey Kong wasn't seen just as a homage to King Kong, it was actually seen as COPYRIGHT INFRINGEMENT. Universal Studios sued Nintendo after they refused to give Universal royalties.

However, in the case in (Universal City Studios, Inc. v. Nintendo, Co., Ltd.), Nintendo's lawyer had done his homework and looked up a previous case relating to King Kong. In Universal City Studios, Inc. v. RKO General, Inc., Universal successfully argued that King Kong was a public domain character and story (which allowed the studio to make it's 70's remake of King Kong without paying for the rights or any royalties). The judge ruled against Universal Studios, he also found Universal's King Kong game was actually infringing NINTENDO'S copyright.

The lawyer in this case? His name was John KIRBY. Yes, Nintendo named one of their characters after a LAWYER.
Packman was renamed because of the pronunciation ("paku" sounds more like pack than puck, since Japanese phonetics doesn't have a schwa).
